Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

My Residence hall is currently running a large game of assassin. For those of you unfamiliar with the game, each player is assigned a target. The player is tasked with eliminating that target from the game, after which they inherit the target's target.
In this particular game, the way you "assassinate" your target is by placing a clothespin on them.
Being an engineer, I noticed that a clothespin is not really well designed to surreptitiously attach to someones clothes. They are meant for easy removal, which is also not desirable. The jaws are shaped inefficiently, the wood slides easily, etc. So I set out to make a Tactical Clothespin.

The final design is based on an existing clothespin by Thingiverse user PolygonPusher. It has lengthened, pointed, serrated jaws to easily grab and hold onto clothing.

title: Firefly - Side panel for Naze32 version 6a board

description.text:
For this item: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:958541
Existing side panel didn't give me the correct access to the USB programming slot for my Naze32 version 6a board. I created the hole using sketchup to align it with the Naze32.

This is under the assumption that below the Naze32 is the PDB board which lift the Naze32 to align with the programming hole.

I made two versions of this. One with a large opening - as USB cable head varies in size so the bigger the better. The second version has a bridge on top to give a nice rectangle hole version which fits my USB cable perfectly.

Simple printable cleat for thin to medium rope and light loads.  
Do not use for climbing or yachting.

comments.text: Hey, looking at it this could be improved to be much easier to use.  Instead of a hole through the center, make it a U shaped slot, open up to the top.  Then put fin type teeth in toward the center to grab the rope, just push the rope down into it instead of having to thread it through.  Then wrap a time or two around the ends, and push the rope into the center slot / teeth again.  Should end up very secure without threading or tying anything, just pushing it into the slot to secure.
comments.author: titlips

comments.text:
Good idea but with a slot at the top it wouldn't be as solid as it is now.
Also the hole is mostly there for decorative reasons. Usually you don't put the rope through the hole. It's only used when the rope won't be detached from the cleat ever.
comments.author: titlips

comments.text:
"the hole is mostly there for decorative reasons" " It's only used when the rope won't be detached from the cleat ever. "
And why is that? Oh yeah because it's terribly inconvenient to put the rope through the hole while winding, even though it would be more secure. A slot fixes that and makes it an easy matter of course.

Nice cleat! Somehow I did get the impression this might be a good image to suggest: http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Knot_cleat.jpghttp://commons.wikimedia.org/w... :)

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Keychain Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Recent Changes:

  • Models revised and updated. HDMI port position adjusted.

This is my first upload to Thingiverse. I was having difficulty finding a Pi Zero case that printed and fit well, so I made my own. :)

It is loosely based on Cowkitty's case design, however I was having issues getting it to print on my RepRap clone. It was made in OpenSCAD and designed to be printed at 0.2mm, both the Zero and the cover should fit snugly in the base. The top cover will need gentle twisting to fit it in it's place.

To remove the Zero, gently twist the case back and forth while lifting with the HDMI port. Just be mindful of the connectors within it.

The revised case will hold all versions of Raspberry Pi Zero securely enough to use as a keychain PC. I do not recommend using ball-chain keyrings if you are going to take these out of the house as they often come loose or break. Beware of any chains used to hold the case as they may contact the Zero when it is powered.

If something doesn't print or fit well on your printer please let me know.

description.text:
What do you do when your 7 year old son loses a #chess piece?
You have him #make a #3D model and print a new one!

Well, it wasn't quite that easy -- I helped A LOT, but he did get his hands on the keyboard quite a bit. I don't recommend this exercise unless you know how to do it yourself already. My kid didn't have the patience to wait it out while I figured out some issues.

It was a great way to spend some time with him and teach him a few things.

So, here it is. Nothing fancy, but it does the trick.

There is a bit of an overhang issue that I didn't bother fixing, but the raw files are attached if you want to take care of it. Please post it back so others can benefit.

If you like it, please click the like button. I want to be famous and with your help.... :-)

description.text:
This is a base that I made for a Lego Pinewood derby car for scouts of all ages. I have not tested to see if it meets regulation, but the sizes are all within spec!

NOTICE: I am not affiliated with LEGO(Creative LEGO Group) nor the BSA(Boy Scouts of America)

I needed to lighten my default extruder head (I have Reprap Mendel Prusa from FolgerTech), therefore I splitted it in two: a bowden extruder on a side and a JHead (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1436575) on the other.

Of course I looked on existing extruders and I didn't found a full satisfying model.
As usual I decided to make my own.
I got inspiration from two things:

  • The first : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73082 for the main structure with the step motor adjustment and the visibility to filament on an efficient driving bolt (you have to made one from cylinder head bolt. MoonCactus described it).
  • The second : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53690 for the great idea of a vibration absorber.

I printed an existing gear set from : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:97377
Then I found a traction spring in my workshop storage, I though that it should be usefull and make access to filament easier.

I designed the BowdenExtruder with OpenSCAD in case of change of screw, spring, bearing, bolt, ... modification.
I use a 1.75mm ABS filament.
I did it quickly and dirty (I'm no very proud of the code and it's not bugless), but I choose to publish it as customizable anyway.

Enjoy :)

Update 2016/04/19:

I realized that two problems came with my first tube holder version:

  • Its independency with the core makes it flexible, therefore it is pushed and pulled during the print.
  • The tube is squeezed if the holder has been screwed too tightened, therefore the filament scrapes into the tube.

I've integrated the tube clamp, already present in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73082, that I removed because of my printer precisionless (that's why I try to upgrade it).
I cross my finger, hopeful, waiting to print it...

I needed to lighten my default extruder head (I have Reprap Mendel Prusa from FolgerTech), therefore I splitted it in two: a bowden extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1436572) on a side and a JHead on the other.

Of course I looked on existing JHead / E3D holders and I didn't found a full satisfying model.
As usual I decided to make my own.

I tried to install my previous version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:939956) but the sensor bracket has broken and I didn't persisted.
Lately I identified that some of my print quality troubles came from an extrusion cooler missing so I had one.
In order to have an extrusion cooler close enough to the hotend, I removed LED ring and choose to move lights around bed, attached to the printer body.

I designed it with OpenSCAD in case of change of screw, JHead, ... modification.
I did it quickly and dirty (I'm no very proud of the code and it's not bugless), but I choose to publish it as customizable anyway.

Enjoy! :)

description.text:
I scored a free rigid futon off the garbage. heck yeah I was taking that. its the solid ones with a fixed bottom fixed back that folds flat (not the frame with cushion type) anyway it has 4 metal legs and 2 were missing the plastic scuff feet inserts.

I thought HEY I have a 3d Printer now. I bet I can make em!

measured 3DS print. just 2 cylinders. for some reason it came out exactly 1mm smaller than I designed. I designed the insert for 73mm it printed 72mm. odd so I scaled it up 1mm and it was super tight fit. got it partly in took my palm and WHACK. smacked right into place. its NEVER coming out without destroying it. Looks factory perfect fit. Nice.

the first one (which I will still use since I need two and don't want to waste it) is also neat since it has no top or bottom (oops I turned that off for printing my rocket tubes and forgot to reset that setting fixed for the black one)

will add some tape to this one to friction fit it and use it as well.

I doubt this will be useful to anyone else unless you have the exact same futon but what the heck might as well post it. I designed it and its genuinely useful. I am happy. fixed a free garbage score for about 25 cents in plastic.

the fuzz in the black one was not printed. thats just some residue when I dremeled the edge to make it easier to insert into the leg.

author: esolares

title: MARLIN Firmware for PRUSA I3 - Sunhokey

description.text:
Hi,
I've just received from Sunhokey their last version of the MARLIN firmware for the Sunhokey's PRUSA I3.

I've uploaded it in my new MKS Gen-2Z V1.2 motherboard, and everything just went fine. I even adapted the configuration to accept a 12864 Graphic LCD Display (from the factory, there is a 2004 screen on their printer). It worked perfectly and at the first attempt.

Attached here is the file for the ones in need.

My advice (from a beginner)... Before opening it, just study in various good blogs how to configure the MARLIN software. It is what I did and I've rapidly got a wider understanding of this matter, enough to feel confident to go further.

You will discover that this sofware is complex (a lot of parameters may be modified), but not complicated (each step is easy to configure when we give some attention to it).

Moreover, you will discover that this software is also suitable for almost all kinds of common motherboards and printers, which then can the be easily setup once the basic principles of the software will be understood.

A last thing, this version given by Sunhokey is ready to be used with their printer.

Hope it helps...

comments.text: Hi, are you sure this is based on 1.1.0 RC3? Asking this because your files have modification date of Wednesday, 17 June 2015 whereas RC3 was released in December 2015. Did you upload an old rar? Please explain.

comments.text:
Hi farrukh.
You are perfectly right, something was not OK in my presentation.
So, I corrected my comment dated 12/08/2016 which contained the mistake.
I hope that now everything is clear again.
Thank you for your very useful feedback.
comments.author: farrukh

comments.text: Nevertheless I tried your firmware and it worked fine but then I decided to go for the latest RC7 because main purpose for newer firmware was bed levelling support. So I downloaded the RC7 from github and casually configured it. It's working fine too. Printed a 0.1 resolution nut bolt thing and it came out perfectly. There is clear difference in motion as compared to previous ones. I don't know if it is due to firmware or the configuration but so far I'm satisfied with it. Here is the link if anyone interested: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1736525/

comments.text: My SD CARD shows "inserted" but in the menu it says NO SD CARD and when I click on it there are no files showing. I tried a 256gb card and the 8gb card. I formatted both fat32 and fat. What is wrong?
comments.author: Trendkilla254

comments.text:
Your problem remind me that when I used my 3D printer for the first time, I encountered the same symptoms.
I've spent many evenings trying to solve this issue, unsuccesfully.
I later understood that I had recorded ".stl" files on my SD card instead of the ".gcode" ones (the latters are the ones created by the slicer and are the only ones which are recognizable by the printer).
Then I recorded the ".gcode" files on the SD card, and everything worked fine.

author: kdupke

description.text:
There was a flimsy little plastic coupler that snapped between the counterbalance lever and spring of my dishwasher door, causing both to be missing and for the door to flop down too fast when I open it. After spending about $6.50 at O'Reilly's Auto Parts for an assortment of springs, I had to create this lovely replacement for the other missing part and get that door back to normal operation.

In the incredibly unlikely event that there is another soul, out there, somewhere who has run into a similar situation, take the enclosed file and print at 100% infill with full support. You'll have what you need to make everything right again.

If you are that rare kindred spirit, make sure you share a pic if you happen to print one out (it makes my day each time someone prints something I designed) and be sure to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: Lekkybits
remixed_from.title: Servo driven ball raced & geared pan/tilt

title: Modified base for "Servo driven ball raced & geared pan/tilt"

description.text:
Updated
I have made some small adjustments after printing. Consider this a functional beta. Let me know if you experience any problems with the design.

This is a modification to the "Servo driven ball raced & geared pan/tilt" to allow for >360* pan when using a 6T sail winch servo. This is designed to mount on two sides of a platform, with the gear drive mounted under the pan/tilt. A double BB race should increase overall stability.

The file "Geared_pt_top.stl" is the remaining parts from original geared p/t to complete the assembly. One slight change was made to reduce support needed, as my printer struggles with support adhesion.

This is the servo I'm using for 360* pan:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=65739

These are the screws I used to mount the sail servo bracket to the base plate:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__57851__3x35mm_Countersunk_Screw_with_shank_10pcs_pack_AR_Warehouse_.html
And these are used to connect the base of the pan gimbal to the bottom raced gear:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__18266__5x30mm_Countersunk_Screw_10pcs_pack_.html

MUCH Thanks to Lekkybits for his original design.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:898517

1. Print the thing
  2. Slightly bow the paperclip (bend just the longer end)
  3. Cut the paperclip
  4. Insert long, bowed end into bottom holes
  5. Insert shorter end through top holes
  6. Bend shorter end forward, which will hold battery down
  7. Bend one end to hold the paperclip in place
  8. Slide battery in from thinner side
  9. Solder wires to paperclip ends
  10. You're done (had to include a 10th step)

title: Banana Loungers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Banana Loungers are a very cool way to store your bananas!

If these were commercialised and on sale in a trendy store you would pay $$$ for something so unique and novel. Fun and practical to use at home and great "unique" gifts.

When you have a few Banana Loungers your Bananas won't want to sit in a crowded fruit bowl any more...so this design alleviates crowding in your fruit bowl and also overcomes bruised bananas... and separating your bananas from their bunch reportedly makes them last longer.

Banana Loungers are an easy print in PLA with no support required as long as your machine has an effective filament fan to help deal with the angles and bridging required. ABS may be a bit more challenging so automated support may be required.

Print a bunch in your choice of colors... they're sure to be a real talking point when guests see them.

Please refer to the print settings and images for additional information.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my fun and practical designs... and post photos of your Bananas Lounging!

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 2

No

Standard / 0.20mm in PLA

3 or 4 Shells / 30% or more infill... as they need to support the weight of a large banana

Notes:

Easy prints but use at least 3 shells and 30% infill to ensure they are strong and support the weight of even large bananas well.

comments.author: Fumbler

comments.text:
Yet another awesome creation. If only I had half the design imagination that you have.
In the sixth picture, it does look like the tongue that the banana sits on might be a little too short and cause bruising at the end.
Have you seen this happen?
comments.author: SpikeUK

comments.text: Thanks for the comment. On early versions that worked a different way the bananas were prone to some bruising which is why I increased the cradle to the size and shape it now is. In the published version l haven't noticed any bruising issues but it is possible if it was a really big / long / heavy banana
comments.author: SpikeUK

comments.text:
Thanks for replying Murray, My question was based purely on my theory after looking at the pictures ... which turned out to be wrong.
I have now printed one of these and the cradle is longer and more supportive than I first thought.
I should have known better than to question your designs, fantastic as always mate.
Will post a make in a moment of course.
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: ...having said that I got home tonight after a couple of days away and one very long banana I had sitting in a lounger (now over-ripe) does have some marking on the underside so it may be slightly bruised... however to get to this the skin needs to start deteriorating (losing its protective layering). This issue made me redesign it a number of times to get what should be a great / fun / result while minimising print time and filament use.... but with really big bananas if you leave then too long you may get a little bit of bruising... but at least they'll still look cool!
comments.author: SpikeUK

comments.text:
If you leave them too long they will over-ripen, whatever you put them in. The magnificent Banana Lounger does not make them any more susceptible to bruising.
And, they are so cool!

This fat little cat sits atop your yarn bowl and poops your yarn out.

Take your chosen container and drill a 10mm hole through the lid. Press the 2 halves of fat cat together using a little super glue to secure the pieces together and your yarn bowl is done! Fat cat will happily poop out your yarn.

My wife likes to knit and crochet and asked me to make her another Yarn bowl.
Print it on its buttstock with brim and supports touching build plate. It isn't perfect, but still fun.

Getting tired of always searching for the correct tweezers between all the pens and pencils, I created this small tool holder. By using 2 layers with the same size holes, all the tools with stick up straight instead of falling to the sides.

You can easily adapt this for your own tools by modifying the holes in the top en mid layer.

It's designed to be cut on a lasercutter out of 3mm thick material. I used some 3mm thick MDF scrap.

CGto3DPrint is a free software that converts 3D CG(Computer Graphics) models to 3D printable manifold 3D models using MeshLab for surface mesh to voxel conversion and Blender for baking color textures.

Converted 3D models are automatically exported from Blender to STL file for single color 3D Printing or manually exported to PLY file for full color 3D Printing.

description.text:
This is reusable Mold for an E3D V6 Silicone Cover (only for clamped-thermistor V6 heater blocks), i got this idea from the german youtuber sehertest who made a similar mold for the merlin hotend.

The Mold consists of 3 parts, which are held together by a M4 screw and a 6mm steel rod, if you dont have a suitable rod you could also use the smooth part of a 6mm drillbit.
It is possible to use magnets to mount a vibration motor on the rod.

you will need about 5.5g of high temp silicone. (i used this one http://www.ebay.de/itm/TFC-Dubliersilikon-S-ROT-mittelhart-Shore-33-1-1-HB-500g-/391144979833?hash=item5b120ebd79:g:6-gAAOSwstxVVfpu)

Before using, remove the support in the hole of the inner mold and drill out the holes of the inner and outer mold with a 6mm drill

and as always, the freecad file is included

These are two caps for a 25mm PVC pipe used as floating handle for Gopro, the original one is too expensive...I cover the pipe surface with carbon fiber adhesive film for better look and glue the caps using epoxy glue, 120 mm was enough to ensure Gopro flotation.

I print using 0,1mm layer for better finish..

Enjoy and save money!

title: Aquarium Moss Shelf - Stackable and Square

description.text:
Please tip as all the tips go to a charitable cause!

Just designed this. Might be a bit over engineered, but here we have:
Moss Shelf for Aquariums or Terrariums.

Slots and Holes primarily for flow and dirt to fall through.

Some design details:
Large rectangular slots for flow
Small rectangular slots for thread loops
Side slots (half circle) for thread adhesion as well
Small holes (3mm) next to feet for stacking (as per attached picture)

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Print with a raft if need be.

Print in clear/natural PLA at 100% infill
40-50mm/s
Do not place in marine tanks or areas of flow like filters or sumps as the PLA will degrade faster.

remixed_from.title: K-Cup Holder for Keurig Coffee Makers

description.text: This is a simple one-piece rack to hold Keurig k-cup coffee containers. Just slide 5 k-cups into the groove on the back of the stand.  The holes let you see the labels of the pods.

This thing uses virtually the entire width of the Replicator 2 build plate.  So it might be a test of the levelness of the platform.  It is too tall to print upright, so keep it on its back as shown in the picture.  
Printed with PLA using the 'standard' settings in MakerWare, but with 25% fill, 0.2 layer height, 2 shells, and increased speed while traveling to 175mm/s (because of the large distance to traveled).  Does not require raft or support.  (The "ridge" on the back, which holds the lip of the k-cup, has a minimal overhang with chamfers to better adhere to 45 degree rule.)  
With these settings, on my printer, the object took 1 hr 14 min to print, and weighs 18 g.  
Once printed, just slide up to 5 k-cups (i.e., a sampler pack) into the rails.  If the k-cup is 'ballooning' out, you may need to press it against the rack in order to slide it into the groove.

text_vertical_position = 0

The tangential oscillating cutting knifes (TOCK) are used for cutting cardboard, rubber, plastic films, etc. They use a sharp edge knife which is moving (oscillating) in vertical direction and in the same time can be rotated to follow the tangent of the curve.
The oscillation of the knife up/down is done through a DC motor from some old ink jet printer, the rotation of the knife is done through stepper motor.
Normally the price of the TOCK is exceeding 1200 EUR and here you can make fully functional TOCK for less than 80 EUR on your 3D printer.

You'll need a CNC machine or router to connect the TOCK head, also one additional axis to control the rotation.

Here you can find a complete documentation how to build such TOCK by using 3D printer.

Video in YouTune showing how TOCK works on cardboard for making boxes (notice the smooth cutting of rounded shapes)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9aJhzyOltiY

Attached is also the program which takes PLT and converts it into GCode with the following features:

  • if the angle of the segment is bigger than some threshold - lifts the head. rotates it to the new angle and bring it back. This improves significantly the cutting quality of sharp edges
  • the program optimizes the order of cutting segments to minimize the head lift
  • the program makes possible to do the creasing without changing the tool (the knife was moved down partially and rotated by 45 deg to make semi cut). Lines in PLT file with red color are treated as creasing lines.
  • The program can also take GCode and add tangential commands
  • The generated GCode can be executed on Mach3

Oil less bushes are from RS components:
http://export.rsdelivers.com/product/rs-pro/ob5812/oil-less-bush-8mm-od-x-5mm-id-x-12mm-l/5217758.aspx

The shaft is calibrated 5mm steel, if using hardened steel shaft it will be more difficult to drill the holes (you'll need carbide drills).

The stepper motor is standard Nema17 42x42x38 or 42x42x48 with 200 steps per turn. technically you can use motor with more or less steps - it's possible to adjust this in Mach3
http://www.amazon.co.uk/3D-Printer-NEMA17-Stepper-Motors/dp/B00KS6I58A

I'll add in the next few days more info about some details (like stepper motor, shafts, oil less bushes, etc.), images of the working head and links to video on YouTube - stay tuned!

Adde IGES model of the design in case you can't open the SolidWorks files.

04/10/2016 - Increased limits of feed rate in Software

Adding the oil less bushes

The bushes are from RS Components (part number 521-7758)
http://export.rsdelivers.com/product/rs-pro/ob5812/oil-less-bush-8mm-od-x-5mm-id-x-12mm-l/5217758.aspx

Another bushes could also be used but the oil less bushes offer long life, can withstand large forces and have low friction so they are ideal for this application.

The holes created during the 3D printing are not very precise - diameter and colinearity are far from ideal. Adding the oil less bushes should be done in the following steps to allow smooth movement of the shaft:

  1. before you start the procedure ensure the bushes move freely on the shaft

  2. Insert the bushes into the holes, use rubber hammer to push them to the bottom of the holes.

  3. Insert the shaft 5mm. It's not necessarily to drill the holes in the shaft on this stage, actually drilled holes will make things more difficult.
    Notice that the shaft goes with effort through both holes

  4. Use hot air gun (300 degrees Celsius, strong blow) for ~20s to 1 min to heat one end of the shaft. Ensure the hot air is not heating the plastic.

  5. Once the shaft is hot enough (it should be between 100-140 degC) push the hot end down to go inside one of the bushes. In 10-20s you'll see that the shaft moves freely inside the hole
    Warning - when you heat the bushes from the shaft some oil is coming out of them. Don't move and push the shaft and bushes at this moment until they completely cool down otherwise it's possible to increase the hole diameter of the main body and get gap between bushes and body.

  6. Do the same operation as (5) for the other bush.

Once you completed steps 1..6 your shaft will move freely up and down. If the shaft can fall out by its own weight from the holes - the friction is OK. If you still have friction - repeat step 5 & 6.

The blade

The blade should be sharp and strong enough. The current design uses blade from cutting knifes (see picture below). You can get spare blades from Farnell

http://uk.farnell.com/ck-tools/t0953-10/blade-trimmimg-knife-9mm/dp/2469271

Break one piece, shape it on grinding stone and make it sharp. Later I found that some blades on the market could be used directly (but this will require some change in the 3D models):

http://uk.farnell.com/swann-morton/0102/blade-10a-f-handle-3-5a-pk5/dp/1551281?ost=1551281&selectedCategoryId=&categoryName=All+Categories&categoryNameResp=All%2BCategories

http://www.amazon.com/SDI-1361-Snap-off-Precision-Degree-20-Blades/dp/B00U9X32BC

Good quality Olfa blades - 30 degrees
http://www.amazon.co.uk/A1160B-CARBON-TINTING-FITTING/dp/B019MX1PQI/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1459333844&sr=8-2&keywords=olfa+30+degrees

Shaping the blade Knife holder assembly

The knife holder was 3D printed, two main parts were tighten with 3mm screws to hold the blade. A metal insert was used to redirect the forces from the blade to the base material - it's a thin strip of steel sheet metal - see images below.

Rotating shaft unit

The shaft rotation is done with stepper motor. The simultaneous rotation of the shaft and the movement up and down is done through the shaft lever and stepper motor lever coupled by two balls 6mm diameter (from ball bearing). The balls touch into two sheet metal bars (so contact is metal - metal), lubricate this area with grease. A 2.5mm screw was used to support the balls and to keep them in the center position. The hole diameter for the balls is increasing inside the body so when you push the balls they will snap and stay in place.

See image below for detailed view of this area.

Assembly holes

There are several holes in the TOCK body used in assembly process for supporting parts or accessing screws - see images below.

Supporting the pulley with steel rod when inserting the 2.5mm spring pin Supporting lever when inserting the 2.5mm spring pin Screwing the stepper motor through these holes Screwing the DC motor through these holes Final assembly sequence

The TOCK assembly process is following:

  1. Insert the bushes and ensure the shaft is moving up/down free (see description above). On this stage remove the shaft

  2. Insert the push-pull pulley and then insert the shaft through the bottom bush and pulley. Use supporting rod and hammer the 2.5mm spring pin into the pulley. Now the pulley is fixed to the shaft. The push-pull pulley is the most critical part of the assembly, if 3D printed it should be used 100% fill and draft quality (to get maximum strength) or it should be be made on lathe from aluminium or brass.
    Grease should be placed to lubricate the contact with the bearing, between bearing and the pulley you need gap of 0.1 to 0.3mm in order to work correctly.

  3. Put he screw on the shaft lever and then insert the balls (6mm diam). The balls should get support from the screw and stay tight in place. If the holes for the balls are too small the lever can break while inserting the balls.

  4. Insert the lever onto to shaft, put the supporting rod and hammer the spring pin. Now the pulley and the lever are fixed to the shaft

  5. Insert the stepper motor into the hole and also add the stepper motor lever. Screw the stepper motor through the mounting holes.

  6. Screw the sheet metal plates to the stepper motor lever. Ensure they move free when inserted over the balls. If they stay tight - push apart the plates, if too much gap - push them inside. Insert some amount of grease between the sheet metal plates for lubrication the contact balls - plates.

  7. Insert the bearing into the motor cap and then both parts into the push-pull pulley. From other side insert the DC motor for oscillation and screw it. Use metal O-ring to avoid bearing to come out from the cap, the gap between cap and bearing should be minimum and the bearing should stay tight on the cap.

  8. Fix the DC motor to the box with 2 screws (by using the holes in the box you can insert the screwdriver).

  9. Add some grease on the main shaft near the bushes. The bushes are oil less and they can work without lubrication but adding grease may prolong their life.

  10. Screw the cover of the box. The cover could be 3D printed or made from 1mm sheet metal aluminium (in this case you get better appearance).

  11. The DC motor is normally powered from 24V but you can find the most suitable voltage for you depend on the motor type. It's a good idea to connect the motor to some relay on the CNC controller board and switch on the motor through GCode.

... to be continued...

Adjusting the zero level for cutting/creasing

The zero Z level is defined as the lowest cutting point, in zero Z level the knife should touch the bottom surface (some soft plastic or rubber base). The problem with cardboard is that you can't rely on the material thickness and use the top surface as zero reference, that's why I chose the bottom surface which is more reliable.

How to find the zero Z level point:

  1. Lift the head over the cardboard surface and position it in some area where the base material (soft plastic or rubber) is visible.

  2. Run the DC motor so the knife is oscillating.

  3. Slowly move down the head until there is a small contact between the knife and the base. The knife in down position should penetrate a little in the base material (0.1..0.2 mm) otherwise the cut details will not come out easy.

  4. Set this level as zero level
Adjusting the creasing level

The TOCK can do also creasing by doing partial cut of the paper (cut half thickness) and also rotating the head on 45 deg relative to the movement vector to maximize the cut area. Such approach has some advantages - there is no need for second instrument for creasing (with separate Z control) but it's applicable mainly for cardboard.

The creasing level is set in the following order.

  1. Find the zero cutting level - described in previous text

  2. Run the motor and start moving the head up until it barely cuts the material. If you cut two layers cardboard ensure you cut the top layer but bottom layer stays intact. The Z level at this moment is the creasing level.

  3. Set also the lift head distance for creasing and cutting to be 3-4mm above the top surface level.
Setting of axis A (rotation) in Mach3

In order to make the generated from the program GCode working it's important to set the Mach3 correctly (if you go to SETTINGS tab in the "Tangential cutting" program there is a short instruction).

Required settings for Mach3 program:

In Mach3 Config /General do the following changes :

  • Uncheck A axis is angular (Mach3 angular degrees do weird things so switch it off).
  • Uncheck Rot 360 rollover (the program takes care for 360 rollover internally)
  • Uncheck Ang short rot on G0
  • Uncheck Rotational soft limits (soft limits on A axis doesn't make sense).
  • Check "Constant Velocity" mode (makes the movent on curves smooth)

In Settings (Alt-6) - uncheck Tangential Control

Motor tuning for A axis - make settings in such way that 1mm movement on A axis yields 360 degrees rotation. The steps per mm settings in Motor Tuning for A axis is calculated by following formula:

steps_per_mm = motor_steps * microsteps

In case of Nema17 motor with 200 steps and if using stepper driver with 8 microsteps the result is:

steps_per_mm = 200 * 8 = 1600

Ensure you set properly the maximum velocity and the acceleration (the settings below are suitable for Nema17 with 8 microsteps).

Don't forget to press Save Axis settings button after changes were made (otherwise changes will be lost).

When using M07/M08/M09 for switching on the cutting motor ensure file M101.m1s contains (the macro can be generated from the program by pressing button in SETTINGS tab):

Call SetDRO (3,0)
Code "G4 P1"

If needed you have to invert the direction of A axis in Mach3 settings.

If you don't have homing for A axis you have to force the head to zero angle manually after main machine homing. In current design the stepper motor is directly rotating the head so it's possible to overcome the stepper motor holding force and bring the head into zero position manually. The other option is to use jogging for A axis in Mach3 and rotate the head to the desired position.

After the head was rotated in zero position don't forget to press "Set to Zero" A axis (set current A position as zero).

Hi Lubo
You give me good ideas. It reminds me of the new "kalashnikov" with conraweight. My current set up / two tools attached to one belt, so when one goes up the other down, so with one motor you control 2 tools./ is ideal to test it. And the tools act s weight and counterweight, possibly adding springs to soften the end hit. Im doing upgrade now and will check like this later on. https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-HTbUSlKiUTMVZsei0ybEp2elU/view?usp=sharing
I intend to test it . What do you think about it?
About Mach 3:
I have to add that the g1 z1 move is just "trick" to prevent the mach3 spinning in the material on the way out. You can do any distance. It seems mach looks at the next move and spins the blade to be ready for it. So, giving it a small move up "tricks" it not spin and the "original" Z move goes normally...This is in absolute coordinate mode. If its relative mode probably have to take it in account.
Best

comments.text: The way the program works with GCode-GCode conversion is to take one line and to look for XYZ commands in order to calculate the angle (looks forward to set angle to current command). It keeps into the memory one line of data to get idea for the rotation angle. G2 and G3 have XYZ data which fools the program. I made a small modification to skip lines with G2/G3 and uploaded the new program version V1.7 into Thingiverse. A LED will alert the user that G2/G3 commands were found and maybe the generated code is unusable or compromised.

***Too tight ! Wait for update before print.

In the mean time I just found this alternative:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1405997/#files

REmix from the original Centriphone for the One Plus One

https://github.com/nicovuignier/centriphone

Also here to find:

https://tinkercad.com/things/6WmjVMEmTfa

I'll print it later on and give feedback here:

24/03/2016
The design is based on a OPO cover (don't where I got it anymore) which work probably fine due to the flexibilty of it.
But in this remix, all is rigidified, so this a too tight fit for the phone. I barely took it off the design with out breaking it.
I'll have to redesign it, r if you really want to print it, add a few % scale maybe....
The rest of the structure look nice.
For the moment I will use a bit of dremel here and there and give it a try like this.

Stay tuned...
Penitent in a Holy Week procession at Spain

title: Lens centering ring for 40W laser cutter / engraver

description.text:
I have a generic-cheap-ebay-40W-laser-cutter (sometimes called DC-K40) and the lens is smaller than its holder, making it lying off-center and sometmes at an angle.
This is the solution!

-Print (0,2mm layer is fine)
-cut the ring open with a pair of pliers There will still be about 0,5mm of play but this is to make sure you can remove it some day...

title: Talisman Holder, i.e. Septagon Box and Lid

description.text: Septagon box 20 mm per side, 25 mm deep. Why a septagon? Well, partially because the wikipedia says, \"is not constructible with compass and straightedge but it is constructible with a Makerbot.\"  Okay, I added the Makerbot part.  Anyway it was fun, and I\'m going to store my four leaf clover inside this seven sided box and set it next to the Makerbot during every build -- at least until I learn more about Skeinforge.

• head zeroed at .022 in. above build plate (thickness of construction cardboard).
  • Speed settings:
    chk,chk,1,1,1.3,26,255,8,1,1,1,55
    Might try 22 instead of 26 next time.
  • Raft settings:
    .55,1.5,1,.375,0,.1,.5,.8,1,.8,.5,2,5,1,1,no,60,2,2,0,0,0,230,230,230,230,220,220.
    Next run I\'m setting the second raft layer to 230. You can see the first raft layer stayed put using .55, but the second layer lifted a bit.
  • jitter=2 still left a line along the side, but I can\'t find an allowed jitter range.

comments.text:
Nice box. I'll make one.
I've been playing with the jitter setting while printing the twisted boxes.
As I interpret it, it's the ratio of start position movement to extrusion thickness... and so the default values are effectively negligible... a value around 20-30 has been sorting the problem out for me with the twisted boxes...
I'm guessing it will wrap - so a value near the perimeter length wont be much good... perhaps 1/4 of the perimeter might be a good bet... 7x20/4=35... I will use this when I print and report back (a few days, hopefully).
comments.author: erisianfront

comments.text: Oops... gotta divide by extrusion thickness... I've been using 0.5... so will use 70 for jitter.
comments.author: erisianfront

author: OSU_FYE

title: Plantar Fasciitis Pain Reduction Apparatus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Applying upward pressure to the foot can temporarily relieve pain associated with Plantar Fasciitis. While apparatuses do exist to do this, many put tension on the toe using a tight fitting sock. This causes discomfort to the toe. This apparatus is designed to put tension on the ball of the foot. This thing was suggested to me by a Physical Therapist who sufferers from pain due to Plantar Fasciitis to help alleviate discomfort!
This is a resting splint for when you are sleeping or relaxing (not walking).

This thing is part of a final project for CPSC 183 Technology and the Law with Prof. Brad Rosen at Yale University. The idea of this project is to ask friends for ideas for physical objects that they would like to have that could be printed on the Makerbot TOM. I have designed them, printed them out and given them to the people who requested them. I also have uploaded them here to Thingiverse to add to the library of physical objects that people find cool, useful, or just plain fun!

Print and clean this part. If you would like to use Velcro, see "Route A". If you would prefer to use plastic buckles, print 2 male buckles from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1416 and 2 female buckles from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1272 to accommodate your straps and see "Route B". Route A - You will also need the following supplies: Knee Stabilizer Brace
3/4 Velcro Straps (~7ft)
3/4 Squishy Foam Strip Attach 2 2ft. Velcro Straps to the printed brace as seen in the picture (wrap them around the center posts and pass through the appropriate hole). Attach 1 3ft. Velcro strap to the knee stabilizer brace (either grab a sturdy component and tie the strap in the middle to it or sew the strap on from the center). Attach the squishy foam strip to the foot-side of the brace. Put on the knee brace, and put the foot brace on the affected foot as seen in the picture (get it into a comfortable position - it may be more comfortable to wear a heavy sock when wearing this so the strap does not hurt your foot). You can now attach the Velcro straps together and put tension on the foot to relieve pain associated with Plantar Fasciitis. Route B - You will also need the following supplies: Knee Stabilizer Brace
3/4 Straps (~7ft)
3/4 Squishy Foam Strip Follow instructions from Route A, but place buckles on each end of the straps to connect and tighten.

This 3D printed object is designed to solve a problem that we come across everyday in my design and engineering class and can be found in every home or workplace. comments.text:
Please do...
I mostly use an old Afinia Up! for this kind of thing, and I am always astonished how good it is for engineering things printed extremely accurately... (excellent filament too...), but some other people have had problems with other printers, so I have also made a file for a test piece if your printer needs to upscale/downscale (I suggest by no more than 1%) available here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1439532 - this should be a tight push fit at the top of the motor.

I wish all printers produced the same thing?

title: Minty Printy Boost V3 Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a parametric box design for a Minty Boost V3 USB Mobile Charger. The recommended Altoids Mints Tin and other boxes had a few issues for my purpose. I wanted something that could:

  • Fit 3 batteries instead of 2 (for a longer charge)

  • LED to signal if it's on or off

  • A switch so that batteries don't have to be stored separately
    • Note the LED has a built in flashing circuit that doesn't need a current limiting resistor. The reason for this is to save current over a regular non-flashing LED and to save component space as well as draw attention to it being on. Minty Boost V3: http://www.ladyada.net/make/mintyboost/ This project also uses OpenScad Font: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6820 for a text warning on the bottom of the minty boost and the title on the top. WARNING: Use this at your own risk. Batteries and MintyBoost get very hot as documented on Adafruits website, particularly with high current devices like the iPhone etc. Batteries are generally designed to safety vent and internal resistance generally increases when they get hot. However there is a remote possibility of a battery exploding or the case melting if the batteries gets too hot. It's a good an idea to keep the cover off the case when charging and if the batteries get too hot, interrupt your charging for a while to allow the batteries to cool.

• Print out the top and bottom (I used 25% fill)

  • Clip the blue sheathing off the terminals

  • Clip the crimp off 1 of the terminals (this will be for the positive lead) and solder to attach wire

  • Open up the end of 2 springs and crimp to 2 terminals

  • Wire everything up, the positive lead goes along the battery channel and is soldered to the terminal

  • Negative gets soldered to the bottom of the spare spring

  • Switch is wired into the negative led, led is wired between positive and negative after the switch

  • Lay out the batteries, springs and adjust fit

  • Use 1/2 packet of Sugru to imbed battery terminals (non conducting epoxy putty is an alternative)

comments.text: Could you run four batteries, two pairs of series batteries in parallel? That should give you 3v but with more capacity.
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: I don't see any reason why you couldn't, provided you use cells that are the same type and all at the same discharge level, so that one isn't dragging power through the others if it discharges first.  It should reduce heating too  in the batteries.  I see it as no different then using a high capacity cell, see here:
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: From Minty Boost to Printy Boost!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Good idea, title changed.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: Jetty,
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: Batteries are in series to give a total of 4.5 Volts.  This equates to a longer run time than 3V (2 batteries) because of the way the Minty Boost works. The Minty Boost converts this to 5V power on the USB cable which is then used to charge your device.
comments.author: 1oldclown

author: losinapetrovski

description.text:
Want to make a simple table?  Here you go!  OpenSCAD source code allows you to change a few simple variables so that you can make your own table.  The corners of the table and the legs are rounded for a nice, smooth finish.  
Print upside down ("top" on your build platform) so that you don't need support material.  
The STL (and the photos) show a 80x65mm surface, on 4mm legs that are 36mm tall.  The surface is 1mm thick, which is remarkably sturdy.  (I print 0.2mm layers on my PrintrBot Jr, so it's 5 solid layers of PLA.)

description.text:
This thing is aimed to be a replacement for HPI Front Bumper #101010.

Modded part

I have also created modded part specifically for my Trophy Buggy 3.5, which I expect to be more enduring than standard one.

  • Added supports which lean on front differential housing.
  • Made it higher, so you can lock bodyshell nose under it - this way snow doesn't get under the nose.

I have front stabilizer installed, so without one you need to make supports longer.
I am not sure how it will fit other #101010 compatible models.

title: Solidoodle MK4 fan mount for PEEK cooling

description.text: This is adapted from Lawsy's MK4 head for the Solidoodle, and provides a place to mount a 40mm fan to cool the PEEK. This is meant to help with a problem where you gradually build up a partial clog (that gets progressively worse) because too much heat is filtering up from the hot end into the PEEK, making the flow intermittent. Actually I think it'd work on an MK3 as well. But not the MK5. I just haven't moved up to the MK5 yet. NOTE that this is NOT intended to aim the fan at the print job, and thus, is not intended to be suitable to use to do print jobs that require that. It's meant to be on all the time to keep clogs from forming in the PEEK. If you want to be cooling the print job too, maybe http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:88660 is what you want.

This mounts in front of the PEEK with the extended part pointing downward, towards the print bed.  The fan then gets mounted onto it, facing to blow inward, with the lower two holes lined with the two in the mount.  Thus, most of the fan will be above this assembly.  
I never actually put this into place because I'm switching to the E3D.

description.text:
We live in an information society. We are surrounded by data but they are not just numbers.
They have a strong impact on our lives, they are real, they are tangible. This project
aims to solidify data in a form perceivable by the senses.

This is a model of the city of Torino (divided by neighborhoods) fully customizable. I used OpenSCAD so that anyone could easily modify and use it with your own data to create a three-dimensional graph.

title: Laser mount for SPA CP1 (Kandar) MK I

description.text:
Edit 25.3.2016: uploaded new version, the previous had smaller holes for nuts which then didn't fit perfectly.

Need 4 M3 screws and 4 M3 nuts. I used imbus ones from RC shop.
The small stick fell off almost immediately so i drilled a hole and put a metal pin there.

I needed this because when I use a moderator for indoor shooting, the sights are not paired. I also thought "Hey, I have a laser pointer at home already".
It fits perfectly but it is not so stable and on 4m it does aprox 0,5cm difference when it moves. Maybe lowering the ball to the bottom will do the trick and stabilise it.
It is MK I version and MK II version will be different and would consist of front mount and back mount to master the stability.

Another extruded aluminum Mendel derivative. This extruded aluminum frame is a quick upgrade to your standard Sells Mendel. It's better looking, roomier and, more importantly, more rigid.

The most up to date files are over at the Github repo: https://github.com/Buback/Prism-Reprap. Just go there and hit the ZIP button over on the left hand side for the files. Instructions are posted on the Reprap Wiki @ http://reprap.org/wiki/Prism. The instructions are preliminary for now, but should be enough to at least give you an idea of how it all goes together. As always, if you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask.

comments.text: How's the build area compared to a Prusa? Is the Z-height any better?
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: The Y is probably the same, but the x could be a bit bigger, since the frame bars aren't in the way anymore. the issue there, though, is that the x carriage would need to be shorter.
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.text: The z height, from the bed to the x rails, is ~210mm but lets say 200 to be conservative. I probably could have gone up another 10mm but the problem was the filament coming out of the wades  was hitting the top crossbar and so you wouldn't want to print in that situation because it would add too much drag and you'd lose steps. That's the only problem with not having the open space at the top, but you really have to go way up for it to be a problem.
comments.author: Pointedstick

comments.author: watsdesign

comments.text: That's hard to answer, because i' had to gut my mendel to get all the important bits. But i can tell you it weighs 13.6 lbs.

title: V2.5 Scalar - Electronic Box for MEGA+RAMPS+LCD2004

description.text:
V2.5

Description

This is the box Version 2.5 of the Ramps + Arduino Mega 2560 + LCD 2004 RRD.
This box was designed for Scalar Family 3D printers.
it will fit 3030 aluminum extrusions.

Each part of the box is a separate plastic part.
Print one of each (no special settings required)
Each part can be screwed together using M3x8 screws. Thermoplastic screws are well fit for this kind of application.

V3.0 is Out! check it out

Version 3.0 is out here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402773
Increase even more the capabilities of your Scalar 3D Printer with this V3.0 electronic enclosure.

Compatibility

This box is compatible with :

  • Ramps 1.4
  • Arduino 2560
  • RRD LCD2004
  • 80mm fan

What to Print

Print one of each Stl file and you are ready to go

Updates

  • 2017.06.12 - Add LCD with marking + add bottom and base plate for 2020 extrusions
  • 2017.01.24 - Add fan holders compatible with E3D PT100 module. Also supports 80 or 60 mm fans. there are 2 distinct parts: Ramps_Box_1.4_PT100-Fan_Front.stl for 80mm fan and Ramps_Box_1.4_PT100-60mm-Fan_Front.stl for 60 mm fan.
  • 2016.08.29 - Added missing top part
  • 2016.03.23 - Original Upload

Your Upgrades/Updates:

  • A top cover for MKS TFT2.8 Touch screen is now available here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2196704
  • (Thanks to http://www.thingiverse.com/warlock4890) Ramps 1.4 Box Side with CAT5 connectors http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1525809

    Special notes:

  • Use Thermoplastic screws (M3x8 are great)
  • You can glue each side on the base, it will increased the box rigidity.
  • There are 2 holes available at the bottom of Ramps_Box_1.4_Bottom.stl.
    These holes are dedicated to help you glue this part to the base part:
    Glue the parts together, insert 2 screws, wait a little bit and remove these screws.

If you don't remove these screws after gluing the parts together, the screws will prevent you from properly placing the box on top of the extrusion profile.

This package is compatible with the Scalar Family 3D Printers (Scalar M and Scalar XL)
The 3D printers kits can be found here:
http://3dmodularsystems.com

Have a great printing experience!

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers
http://www.3dmodularsystems.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/3dmodularsystem
Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/c/3DModularSystems3DPrinters

comments.text: Out of all the designs out there, I quite like this the most. The LCD 12864 panel has the same config as the panel you show. Would you know if they're interchangeable? Except for the mounting tabs, which can easily be cut off, it looks like this is really a universal thing and can be used for any printer. Would this be a correct assumption?
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text:
If you need to use the LCD 12864 i've made an update of this box :
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2402773 (V 3.0 of the box)
It supports Arduino Mega 2560 or Re-arm 32Bits, Ramps 1.4, Raspberry Pi 2/3, E3D PT100 Module board,and both LCD 2004 or 12864.
You might change slightly your firmware configuration file to use either LCD2004 or LCD 12864 however.
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: Thanks very much for the reply. That is exactly what I was looking for.
comments.author: 3DModularSystems

comments.text:
Of course you can use metal screws or even glue the sides. But if you mount/unmount some panels often (on my side i often open the back panel to access wires.) the screws won't bit anymore inside the plastic.
On the other side, you will get less troubles using TP screws.
